title: What is the best solution for living with a child who has a drum set? - Quora

response.answer_text: Lots of options here. Mesh drum heads and plastic cymbals. I think this is the best option, assuming that the child also has a “real” drumset somewhere for developing tone and technique and the home “silent” kit is just for practicing those skills. If they have a school set or a set at a private lesson studio to play on, this can be ideal.Drum silencing pads and cymbal “silencing” pads. These work okay, but I’m not a fan of how they react. The rubber drum pads feel like rubber, not like drum heads, so technique suffers. The cymbal pads do a lot to quiet the cymbals, but they’re not silent. The nice thing about this solution, however, is that you can just remove them to get a full volume, touch sensitive drum set.Electric drum set. This is EASILY the most expensive option. They do make cheap drum sets, but these are terrible for a young player to work on unless there’s literally no other option. PLEASE don’t spend $300 on an electric kit thinking it will be a perfect solution. The drums are not durable, so they will break quickly. They don’t have a lot of dynamic range, so the student will not learn to play quietly or with control (which is easily one of the most important aspects a professional player can have). They don’t sound good and they don’t play well.You can do this, but be prepared to spend 2–3 thousand dollars on a high quality electronic kit that does a better job of approximating the nuance of a real drum set and will last more than a few weeks.Soundproofing. This may seem daunting, but there are some fairly simple things you can do. If the drum set is upstairs, it needs to be “decoupled” from the floor. I’ve seen this done by building two 6x6 ft or 8x8 ft platforms, each with a small lip. Turn one upside down (lip facing up) and tightly fill the space with tennis balls (alternately, carve out indentations for the tennis balls to sit - the idea is that you don’t want the upper platform to roll; just not transfer vibration to the floor). Now put the second platform lip down on top of the tennis balls - ensure the lips don’t touch - and put the drum set atop the platform. Now the vibrations won’t transfer to the floor as much. Obviously, you’ll also want to make sure the doors are tightly sealed (solid core doors are better than hollow).Location, location, location. I’ll never forget the day in eighth grade when my dad came in and said, “I’ve got a present for you!” He walked me out to the barn in the back yard, climbed the ladder to the loft, and there I found my drum set, guitar amp, loud stereo, a light, a TV, and a space heater (it was November). “Here you go, son,” he said, “your very own studio.” I was really excited, but then my eyes narrowed… “Wait a minute,” I said. “This is just to move the drums out of the house, isn’t it?” “Have fun!” my dad called, grinning ear to ear.
